A number input port whose key is
. The value must be expressed in seconds.
Posted when the user selects a composition in the picker view.
Posted when the user chooses a composition.
A composition that renders a generic graphical animation. It has the option to use
for the primary color of the animation,
for the secondary color of the animation,
for the global pace of the animation, and
to indicate if the animation should run in lower-quality for preview purposes.
A  composition that performs a transition between two images, using a transition time in range of
to
. A conforming composition must use the input keys
for the starting image and
for the image to transition to. The composition can optionally use
to indicate if the animation should run in lower-quality for preview purposes.
A  composition that  applies an effect to a source image.  A conforming composition must use the input key
for the source image and
for the output image. The composition can optionally use
to specify the X position of the center point of the effect,
to specify the Y position of the center point of the effect, and
to indicate if the animation should run in lower-quality for preview purposes.
A  composition that acts as a visualizer for music.  A conforming composition must use the input key
for the instantaneous audio peak and the
for the instantaneous audio spectrum. It can optionally use the
to indicate it receives information about the current  track and the
to indicate the start of a new track.
A  composition that acts as a visualizer for an RSS feed.  A conforming composition must use the input key
for the URL to use for the RSS feed. It can optionally use
to specify the duration of each feed article.
A composition that can be used as a screen saver. The composition has the option to use
for a screenshot image of the screen that the screen saver runs on,
to indicate if the animation should run in lower-quality for preview purposes, and
for a  URL to open in the default web browser when screen saver exits (only allowed if screen saver password is disabled).
Posted whenever the list of compositions in the composition repository is updated.
The key for the custom patch description. The associated value is an

The current location of the mouse (as an
object stored in an
object) in normalized coordinates relative to the OpenGL context viewport ([0,1]x[0,1] with the origin (
) at the lower-left corner).

An ARGB8 format. The alpha component is stored in the most significant bits of each pixel. Each pixel component is 8 bits. For best performance, use this format on PowerPC-based Macintosh computers, as it represents of the order of the data in memory.

A  BGRA8 format. The alpha component is stored in the least significant bits of each pixel. Each pixel component is 8 bits. For best performance, use this format on Intel-PC-based Macintosh computers, as it represents of the order of the data in memory.
An I8 format. Intensity information is represented as an 8-bit value.
An If format. Intensity information is represented as a floating-point value.
An RGBAf format. Pixel components are represented as floating-point values.
The key for the port default value. You can use this key only for value ports (Boolean, Index, Number, Color and String).
The key for the port maximum value. The associated value is an
object that specifies the  maximum numerical value accepted by the port.
The key for the menu items.
The key for the port minimum value. The associated value is an
object that specifies the  minimum numerical value accepted by the port.
The key for the port name. The associated value is an
object.

object stored in an
object. The mouse location is in normalized coordinates relative to the OpenGL context viewport (
with the origin
at the lower-left corner).
Posted when the view stops rendering.
Posted when the view starts rendering.
A consumer execution mode. The custom patch always executes assuming the value of its Enable input port is
. (The Enable port is automatically added by the system.)
A processor execution mode. The custom patch executes whenever its inputs change or if the time change (assuming it's time-dependent).
A provider execution mode. The custom patch executes on demand—that is, whenever data is requested of it, but at most once per frame.

An idle time dependency. The custom patch does not depend on time but needs the system to execute it periodically. For example if the custom patch connects to a piece of hardware, to ensure that it pulls data from the hardware, you would set the custom patch time dependency to idle time mode. This time mode is  typically used with providers.]]
No time dependency. The custom patch does not depend on time at all. (It does not use the
parameter of the
method.)
A time base dependency. The custom patch does depend on time explicitly and has a time base defined by the system. (It uses the
parameter of the
method.)
